node.title: Multiphase Flow Of Water Jet in the Air Simulation Using MOOSE.
node.bodyText: Hi everyone! I am trying to simulate multiphase flow of water jet in air using MOOSE to study the turbulence induced liquid sheet breakup process. I am pretty much new with using moose. Can anyone provide me a sample code or step by step guidelines to develop the input code? Thanks.

Hello
You may have a look at the Navier Stokes module to get started.
We dont have any multiphase flow capability currently but the equations have some similarities so this will be a good example
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/navier_stokes/index.html
Guillaume
Thank you for your valuable feedback. can you give me a basic structure of the code that I can follow?

You should first follow the tutorials on how to use MOOSE
then you should determine whether you want to use finite element or finite volume

node.title: SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Team,
I used “SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator” (with block = block # of Block 2) to generate the boundary lines around Block 2 (please see the attached sketch).
It seems that only the Block 2 side of boundary lines are generated.
Namely, I cannot set “NeumannBC” on the Block 1 side of boundary lines.
I would like to apply “NeumannBC” on the Block 1 side of boundary lines as BC and Block 2 is isolated from Block 1.
Please help me generate the boundary lines on the Block 1 side.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas
Boundary_Generation_Around_A_Block.pdf

Hello
There's a few other options here. One that comes to mind, is "between block 1 and 2"
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator.html
Guillaume

Thank you Guillaume.
The challenge here is to set different values of NeumannBC for top, bottom, left, and right sides of the boundary.
I believe "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" takes the same value of NeumannBC for all sides of boundary.
Is my understanding right?
Please help.
S. Thomas

oh right
Can you try this one then? Are the normals all constant on the sides you care about?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator.html

Thank you very much Guillaume.  I will try.
Actually the values of NeumannBC for top, bottom, left, and right sides of the boundary are assigned after the calculations as the temperature dependence, I will modify NeumannBC.C and h for that. Yes, they are normal to the boundary lines from the Block 1 side.
Thank you very much again and I would like to let you know,.
S. Thomas

What do you mean by after the calculation?
Do you mean that the boundary conditions on one domain depend on the variables in the other domain?

Yes, the value of flux is calculated from the concentration at the boundary and temperature.
I hope my idea works.
S. Thomas

If flux, concentration and temperature

are solved within the same input file
influence each other on both sides of the interface (high C causes high flux for example, and high flux is a loss term in the C equation)
you may want to consider an interface kernel instead of a boundary condition.

I thought the assign flux boundary value only  on the Block 1 side and completely isolate the Block 2 side from the computation is more stable.  I don't know ...
Thank you very much for your time and consideration.
S. Thomas

If an interface kernel is used, does “SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator” work?
Please let me know.
S. Thomas
No issue with sidesets for interface kernels. You just choose the variable and neibghbor variable according to the sideset orientation

Dear Guillaume,
"SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator" with "interface kernels" works.
I can set the interface direction from Block 2 to Block 1 by "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" but
I cannot set the top, right, bottom, and left interfaces by "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator".
I would still like to ask if there is a way to set flux on the top, right, bottom, and left interfaces on the Block 1 side without "interface kernels" because there is not enough mesh in Block 2 for the computation.
Please help.
S. Thomas

node.title: MOOSE Docs websites rendering drop-down menus on mobile
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Today, I made live Ferret's website https://mangerij.github.io/ferret/index.html and noticed that the drop-down menus do not render correctly (and are not able to be clicked) if one uses a mobile browser. I checked and this seems to be a MOOSE Docs wide issue since both the drop-down menu on the framework's website as well as other MOOSE-based apps (for example Raccoon, https://hugary1995.github.io/raccoon ) also have this issue. It does not seem to be an issue with the browser used on mobile. I checked Chrome, Firefox, and others and all of the drop-down menus cannot be expanded and clicked on. I figure I would just raise this issue - but it would be nice if there was a work-around...
Can confirm, creating an issue

node.title: Multi nodes computing stuck when using ModularGapConductanceConstraint

Hi,
I am running a simulation on HPC with externally compiled PETSC. The model is a transient themo-mechanical problem with gap heat conduction and radiation formulated by mortar contact constraint. No issue when I ran it on a single node. When running on multiple nodes, at one step the computing is forever stuck at Computing Residual...........(dots till it get killed by TIMEOUT). The specific occurrence time step of such issue is different each time.  No error was reported. No issue when I ran it without ModularGapConductanceConstraint.
I have not tested if this issue is specific to one HPC. I currently do not have access to another cluster.
I will post information about my MOOSE and job later. I am working on producing a smaller problem that can reproduce this issue. Hello
You can use this script to find the hung process
moose/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py
and see where the computation freezes. This should help you debug this.
Otherwise you can start a parallel debugging session and interrupt while it is stuck, then get a backtrace much like for a seg fault issue.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
Guillaume

You can also log in to one of the nodes running your simulation, attach a debugger to the process and print the backtrace from there

@permcody Thank you!  I assume that Sawtooth is a cluster name. No, I am on Sandia's cluster solo. What else about the cluster should I provide you with?

Oh, well then I'm going to need you to do a little digging:
First, take a look at the node naming scheme on that cluster and make sure that the RegEx pattern is correct on this line:

  
    
      moose/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py
    
    
         Line 35
      in
      8b7e46d
    
  
  
    

        
          
           node_name_pattern = re.compile(r'(r\di\dn\d{1,2})') 
        
    
  


Hopefully it just works after that. However, if it doesn't, you'll have to start adding some print statements to see what might be going wrong. The script essentially runs qstat -n <job num>, to get a list of all the nodes on your cluster where your job is running. It uses the RegEx from the line in the first link to locate those in the text. After that it generates a list of ssh commands to pull back stack traces from each one of those job nodes. You'll find all this in this region: 
  
    
      moose/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py
    
    
        Lines 191 to 232
      in
      8b7e46d
    
  
  
    

        
          
           def get_sshpids(application_name, host): 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               Generate and return a valid SSH remote ps command 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               ps_grep = f'ps -e | grep {application_name}' 
        

        
          
               awk_print = r"awk '{print \$1}'" 
        

        
          
               return f'ssh {host} "echo {host}; {ps_grep} | {awk_print}"' 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
           def get_sshstack(host, pid): 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               Generate and return a valid SSH remote stacktrace command 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               return f'ssh {host} "echo Host: {host} PID: {pid}; ' \ 
        

        
          
                      f'{PSTACK_BINARY} {pid}; printf "*%.0s" {{1..80}}; echo"' 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
           def generate_traces(job_num, application_name, num_hosts, num_threads): 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               Generate a temporary file with traces and return 
        

        
          
               formated results 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               hosts = set([]) 
        

        
          
               a_job = Job(f'qstat -n {job_num}') 
        

        
          
               a_job.run() 
        

        
          
               results = a_job.get_stdout() 
        

        
          
               for i in node_name_pattern.findall(results): 
        

        
          
                   hosts.add(i) 
        

        
          
               if num_hosts: 
        

        
          
                   # convert back into set 
        

        
          
                   hosts = set(list(hosts)[:num_hosts]) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
               # Use a Scheduler to get hosts and PIDs 
        

        
          
               hosts_pids = __get_pids(application_name, hosts, num_threads) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
               # Use a Scheduler to get stack traces from each 
        

        
          
               # host for every PID 
        

        
          
               stack_list = __get_stacks(hosts_pids, num_threads) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
               traces = [] 
        

        
          
               for stack in stack_list: 
        

        
          
                   output = os.linesep.join([s for s in stack.splitlines() if s]) 
        

        
          
                   traces.extend(split_traces(output)) 
        

        
          
               return traces 
        
    
  


If something is broken, it'll likely be in that piece. The rest is pretty solid. We right all those results to a cache file that you can just browse with your editor. The second part of the script opens that file and compares all those stack traces to look for stack traces that don't match up. What's tricky about this step is that there's usually some noise in the MPI polling routines so it's normal for the jobs to have unique stack traces if you compare the whole stack. This is where you may have to experiment with the -s <n> argument to see if you can get the stack traces all lined up and agreeing with one and other. At one extreme if you ran the script with just -s 1, it would only pay attention to the first stack from (e.g. main) and they'd all be identical. However, if your program is truly hung, you'll find a spot where you'll end up with two unique "buckets" of traces. Some number of ranks will be in one place, while some number will be in another place. This is bad because both groups are waiting on the others to show up, which they never will (classic deadlock).
All this script debugging is worthwhile!
If you can't figure it out, you should consider applying for an account on our system Sawtooth where we can support you.

If the script is invalid because of password request, I can still send you the input deck and mesh that would cause my issue. It should be reproducible on your cluster as well since I have reproduced it on two clusters I have access to.

The script can be modified to work with slurm. I'm not as familiar with that queuing system, but we really only need to interact with the queuing system to get back the node names where the job is running. As I mentioned before with PBS that's qstat -n. You'll just need to put the equivalent command there that gives you that info with slurm.
I saw in my email that you likely figured out the RegEx pattern for your cluster - good!
Finally, I'm pretty surprised that your cluster requires a password to move from node to node. That would be highly unusual. Generally you need a password or MFA challenge to login to the head node, but then you can SSH to nodes freely from there. In fact that should be required to launch jobs. Are you sure your cluster doesn't support keys? That would be highly unusual as well.
Check with your system admins to see how to setup your profile so that you don't need passwords to move around. You are getting closer!

node.title: 2D random walk Problem
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am looking to model the Brownian motion of say N particles in a 2d domain. How can I implement such model using moose framework. I have simulated such problem in MATLAB and python but how can I implement it in moose? Also I want to implement some rules for further guided movement of particles.
If there are some existing resources please tag here.
Thanks

Hello
I think you will want to use the ray tracing module to do this
We had started a project on something similar but never finished, please feel free to examine the latest commits here:
https://github.com/loganharbour/moose/tree/rt_mpm
Guillaume

can I run a python script (for the random walk) within the moose input file. So that at each time step the python script provides me the position of particles which can be further used by the moose variables and material properties.

No you can't run python within MOOSE right now.
If the logic in the python script is not too complicated, it should be transcribed in the RayKernels / RayTracingStudy objects in the module. This will ensure the most performance as well

No you can't run python within MOOSE right now.

well, the user can always write a userobject to do anything... in this case running a python script.

Is it time for the RunCommand user object?
It's definitely not preferred at this point
I don't prefer that either. I was just pointing out the possibility.

If the logic in the python script is not too complicated, it should be transcribed in the RayKernels / RayTracingStudy objects in the module. This will ensure the most performance as well

OK. Thanks
Will be posting further upon transcribing the python code into RayKernels.

node.title: Applying force boundary condition to a particular set of nodes
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am very new to MOOSE, and currently am trying to compare ANSYS and MOOSE (the idea is to use more of MOOSE in future). The problem I am trying now is a 4-point beam bending test, where in ANSYS we put force boundary condition on a selected curve (set of nodes) as shown in the image below:

Now to do the same in MOOSE, I create the geometry in Cubit and make a nodeset at the same location (since sidesets are not supported in exodus format from cubit :( ), and I want to impose a NeumannBC or PressureBC at these nodes such that I can impose a force. But I see that MOOSE doesn't support applying such boundary condition to nodesets and expect sidesets.
Is there any possible solution or a kernel I can use to impose such BC in MOOSE ?
Thanks,
Aritra

Hello
You may use this boolean in the [Mesh] block to convert nodesets to sidesets:
construct_side_list_from_node_list = true
Guillaume

I am asking because I am not sure if construct_side_list_from_node_list is smart enough to handle the "line" case. Our convention is that side set of a 3D mesh is a collection of element faces (as in topologically 2D faces).

@hugary1995
They do not belong to a specific face boundary, I created an "arbitrary" curve when I generated the mesh in Cubit and assigned the nodes on that curve as the particular nodesets. So yeah, they are not a collection of the element faces. The geometry (and the curve) is the same as I have put in my screen shot, and the red line is where I want to apply the force boundary condition (basically the nodes that are on the red edge).
-Aritra
In that case I think you should use DiracKernels since you can't create a sideset out of it.

You can make a sideset in cubit that will be exported to the exodus mesh:
create surface rectangle width 5 height 3 zplane
mesh surface all
block 1 surface all
sideset 101 add curve 2
sideset 101 name 'centerline'
export mesh "rectangle.e"  overwrite

@lynnmunday thanks a lot for the reply. I actually had tried it but it did not work. When I enquired with Cubit customer support they mentioned:
"Following up on my last email, we've confirmed that the Exodus format does not support sidesets comprised of curves (element edges) on 3D meshes.  You can find this described in the Exodus documentation here: https://sandialabs.github.io/seacas-docs/exodusII-new.pdf in section 4.11"
So for example when I add the sideset in Cubit it shows up:

But when I export the sideset do not transfer to exodus:

-Aritra
@lynnmunday your script works because it's creating a curve sideset on a 2D surface mesh.

@GiudGiud @hugary1995 @lynnmunday
btw, I was able to get a work around for now using the NodalKernel with type: "NodalGravity" which I guess you can use to apply some gravity force on a selected nodes. So I have the following block:
[NodalKernels]
[./force_y2]
type = NodalGravity
variable = disp_y
boundary = 'force_y_left force_y_right'
gravity_value = 1.0 # inverse of nodal mass at cantilever end
function = force
mass = 1.0
[../]
[]
[Functions]
[./force]
type = PiecewiseLinear
x = '0.0  1.0 '
y = '-3.3 -3.3'
[../]
[]
But I am a bit confused in the way the nodal gravity force is calculated. Is it like f = mg?
Looking at the source code I see it returns :
-mass * _gravity_value * _function.value(_t + _alpha * _dt, (*_current_node))
So in my case, does that mean that the nodes in the selected boundary (i.e., my nodesets) will have a force of 3.3 N or is it something completely different than what I am thinking it to be ?
Again, I really appreciate for your time and help.
-aritra

I haven't used this object but what you are describing seems correct based on the code.  You can use the tag system to output the residual from the gravity kernel to see what the force is, like in this test to make sure its correct:
moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/torque_reaction/torque_reaction_3D.i
Then you should be able to look at the saved in lagrange aux variable you create and they should be 3.3 like you expect.

Thanks a lot @lynnmunday ! I will look into it. When you say the tag system, do you have a documentation ? I am sorry I am very new to MOOSE (basically since two days :( )
-Aritra

I couldn't find where extra_tag_vectors is documented. The auxvariable for outputting them is here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/TagVectorAux.html
I don't know how they work but it seems like they are "tagging" certain contributions to the residual into a vector so that they can be output with that nodal auxvariable.
got it, I will look into it then.
